I have seen three ball lightnings hit the field in one turn and it was gg right then and there. 
It is one of thouse few older cards that has actully aged well. R&D knows that this card is loved by many, infact that is why it has seen so many reprints and knock offs. Put simply it is a classic.
Also, if you love Ball Lightning and you perfer to play green (possibly for the mana excel) consider groundbreaker.

1712.content: @ Gaussgoat:Says in the rulings that it's not prevention, so it works even on damage that can't be prevented. Which is quite good.

Says "prevent" right on the card. Why would that be Oracle-updated away? Plenty of red cards care about the difference.Easy to template the right way: "The next time a source of your choice would deal damage to you this turn, prevent half of that damage, rounded down."Of course, this would make the card even less useful, but it's a matter of principle.

"Actually quite good in non-white EDH if your in a meta where Big-One-Shot-General-Hits are making your life miserable. Overall a pretty good 0 drop artifact too (just not better than the creatures, moxes, X spells or the baubles)."
Any spot removal would be better (or a Fog effect, which would at least stop all of the damage). With the sphere, you don't actually solve the problem; the general is still alive and will just kill you next turn. It's doubtful the opponent will have left himself open to a counter-attack, either, as he will have known going into the turn that you had the Sphere waiting. For this reason, he also won't have gone all-in with a card like Hatred or Berserk.

1807.content: I love the utter illogic behind this card. People fast to gain insight or understanding, so technically this card should work more like Necropotence - you take damage (from starving) to gain cards (insight.) Instead, we get a card that is totally useless and doesn't make any sense.

Note that you get the life on your draw step, after upkeep, meaning you get at most eight life, not ten.  So we're looking at gaining eight life over four turns at the cost of very likely losing the game.  If you're losing then skipping your draw step is the absolute last thing you want to do, and if you're in a situation where you can cast this without a major drawback (say, the board is stabilized), then there's no need to use this in the first place.Although I suppose it does combo with Elkin Bottle, but that just seems clunky.This is a card that hinders you far more than it would ever benefit you.  You can't even Donate it because it doesn't require you to skip your draw step.  This is a card that makes you wonder what the testing department was smoking when they let it pass.  See also: Sorrow's Path.

There is "Beginning of Combat Step" (rule 507 on Comprehensive rules) that happens after attack phase is declared but before attackers are selected and tapped if necessary. During this step you can tap any creatures of the attacker and thus make them non-eligible for attack and the opponent cannot back down from the attack phase.
A surprisingly competent card from The Dark. Nice in duels, but really shines in multiplayer, where its Rattlesnake potential is exceptionally high. 4.5 stars!

This card actually has very little rattlesnake potential. You have to be proactive with it, or it doesn't work. It doesn't actually scare anyone, and if you say "are you going to attack me, because if you, I'll tap it", your opponents can always just lie. It's an amazing moveable answer, but it's a terrible rattlesnake.Unless you house rule a declaration of intent to attack before the actual declare attackers step. Then it's a great rattlesnake.

Play online, have a stop set at the Beginning of Combat step, then you never have to worry about telling your opponent to give you priority.  Oh wait, this card still isn't online after like 10 years of mtgo.  Lame.

@LungCancer: Because it's not a zombie. It's a (well, THE) monster. Zombies are shambling, meaty undead, really just animated corpses. This is a living creature made of stitched-together pieces. Also, at this point in the game's history, they didn't make an effort to group things into tribes. The only tribes that existed were specifically synergistic by design, like the 8 goblins who had a goblin king, or the 2(!) zombies who had a zombie master. Everything else went out its way to have a unique creature type (like "summon Uncle Istvan") to avoid accidental tribal synergy.

Building a Suicide Blue -Delver deck. [autocard]Augur of Bolas[/autocard], [autocard]Delver of Secrets[/autocard], [autocard]Serendib Efreet[/autocard],[autocard]Serendib Djinn[/autocard], [autocard]Psionic Blast[/autocard], [autocard]Countersquall[/autocard], [autocard]Go for the Throat[/autocard], and [autocard]Undermine[/autocard].
Something like that anyway. It's amazing how many of the best beaters blue really has for manageable drawbacks and then powerful counter-burn spells. Not positive mind-bomb will make the final cut; but when you consider that delver + this + spell pierce T2 means you're safe from removal and 6 damage in; it's easy to see why it may go main-deck. So I'm looking at DarthParallax's comment, and uh...yeah. I don't think he's sarcastic, considering he posted something similar on the fifth edition version and said to look at his comment here. I [i]hope[/i] he is, though. The only other way that his comment would make sense is if he's playing a game mode where each player has 5 life, red cards are banned, and creatures aren't allowed to do damage.
This card is okay. You can use it just for the damage, in which case its generally a worse [autocard]Lava Spike[/autocard] unless you're in multiplayer. Its a lot harder for blue to take advantage of each player starting with lower life though, unlike red with stuff like [autocard]Flame Rift[/autocard]. Therefore, its best use is probably to discard your own stuff. If you're just trying to reaniimate a big creature, [autocard]Careful Study[/autocard] or [autocard]Entomb[/autocard] are usually better options in just blue and black (you can't really run a mono blue reanimator deck, unless you're using Body Double, in which case a 1 cmc discard spell isn't needed because your deck isn't that fast). The 3 damage you'll usually do to your opponent isn't that important when you're getting out a huge creature turn 2-3, and you'd generally rather have a higher chance of actually having a fattie to discard. I think this card has set a wonderful precedent for the Flicker / Astral Slide effect that has become common today... (Outworldly Journey, Ghostway, Momentary Blink, Vanish into Memory, Glimmerpoint Stag, and Venser, the Sorjourner, just to name a few.)
... which in turns inspires effects like Oblivion Ring and Journey to Nowhere. In a sense, Safe Haven is the great-grandfather of all these cards.

[b]Aaron’s Random Card Comment of the Day #70, 4/1/11[/b]
I love the flavor of [i]The Dark[/i]. The set suffered from having too few cards that were compelling mechanically (Check out this quote from the sell text: “Many cards have tempting abilities, coupled with damaging penalties.” Fun!), but the flavor was very distinct and reasonably well executed. In many ways it reminds me of the upcoming [i]New Phyrexia [/i]set in that it stretched the color pie in flavorful way to show how darkness has crept into all the colors.
Safe Haven has great flavor and mechanics that are unique and costed well enough to be a lot of fun. I made a slew of Safe Haven decks as a younger man and had fond enough memories of it to include it as a “time shifted” card in [i]Time Spiral[/i].
You can tuck creatures that are about to die into Safe Haven (although the M10 rules make that play less devastating), put your creatures in there before you cast a sweeper, or just jam a bunch of guys with cool ETB triggers in there for reuse. The slightly more versatile version of this card is [autocard]Synod Sanctum[/autocard] from [i]Mirrodin[/i], but the flavor of hiding inside a one-mana artifact as opposed to a land feels like a downgrade to me.
If we were to make a land that did something like Safe Have today, it would have to tap for mana, as that’s a rule we’re pretty strict about not breaking (fetchlands don’t count). I do see the appeal of designing lands that don’t tap for mana, however--some lands are for mana, and some are for hiding in… makes total sense--but the game plays a lot cleaner the more closely we can tie the number of lands you have to the amount of mana you can produce.
A “fixed” Safe Haven sounds like a great card for a Core Set some day. Note taken!

@ Aaron:Synod Sanctum does not only have the problem of being a cheap artifact, it also  states: "under your control". This is essential, once you use temporary "gain control" abilities.I really like the fact that this land doesn't produce mana. Similar to a Maze of Ith, this combined a powerful effect with the disadvantage of a missed land drop and therefore a lower mana count. If the land produces mana AND creates an powerful effect, this sometimes feels more like a trick to bypass being a spell. Manlands for example don't really feel like an animated land, but more like some way to avoid counterspells and Wrath of God effects.So if you really add abilities to lands that produce mana, make sure that you either use one-time effects or really focus on the land itself, not the magic you produce.

you could say this card evolved in the history in magic.
[autocard]Standing Stones[/autocard] and [autocard]Celestial Prism[/autocard] are the two oldest and weakest versions of their type.
[autocard]Mana Prism[/autocard] is the stronger version of those two, having the ability to produce colorless mana for free, or requiring one colorless mana and no health point for mana of any color.
if one prefers spending life, [autocard]Phyrexian Lens[/autocard] is also an alternative that's stronger than Standing Stones.
The latest design of them is [autocard]Darksteel Ingot[/autocard], which does not only simply produce one mana of any color without any side effect, but on top of that has indestrictibility.
These days, [autocard]Spectral Searchlight[/autocard] can be used for multiplayergames instead (or maybe even to invoke some mana burn when choosing your opponent), and [autocard]Coalition Relic[/autocard] if you do not fear its destruction and want one extra mana instead.
[autocard]Prismatic Lens[/autocard], again, is the new improved version of Mana Prism, and also about ten times better than Stranding Stones or Celestial Prism :D
This card gets laughed at by Prophetic Prism. It's cheaper, draws you a card when you play it, and doesn't cost life.

The ultimate nostalgia card.  Back in the day this card was the sh*t.  Sometimes I put on my Nirvana Unplugged tape and think about the ultimate The Dark combo: this card and Scarwood Goblins.  Good times...
I was going to make some smarmy comment about this card being outclassed several times over, but I think Glopdemon has put us all in our place. Nothing more needs to be said.

In my humble opinion, [autocard]Darksteel Ingot[/autocard] is slightly overpowered. I believe it's currently finding printing at Uncommon and soon on it's way to Common status if Commander products continue at the they are, it will likely replace [autocard]Sol Ring[/autocard] eventually some year, whenever they decide Sol Ring is unhealthy for the format or isn't needed for every deck. 
This card has many more analogies in MTG history. 
Alpha was [autocard]Celestial Prism[/autocard], yes, 
Arabian Nights did not, I think, have mana artifacts, but I will look them up.
Antiquities of course is [autocard]Standing Stone[/autocard], and Standing Stones is one of my very favorites from the series. [autocard]Ashnod's Altar[/autocard] is much more powerful.
Legends has a full cycle of [autocard]Mana Battery[/autocard]s, whose flavor sadly is out of the ballpark but the mechanics suck.
The Dark has [autocard]Fellwar Stone[/autocard] at least. (others?)
[autocard]Astrolabe[/autocard], [autocard]Barbed Sextant[/autocard], and [autocard]Star Compass[/autocard] always come to mind together and I can never remember which sets they're from.
[autocard]Pentad Prism[/autocard], [autocard]Chromatic Sphere[/autocard], and [autocard]Armillary Spheres[/autocard] also form a family in my mind. 
There's the 1-mana Artifact Mana Stones, which tend to sacrifice themselves to do something
The 2-mana Artifact Mana Sources, which tend to give you the best results because they're narrower, but sharper focused, 
The 3-mana Mana Stones almost always give you either [autocard]City of Brass[/autocard]-variant or [autocard]Sol Ring[/autocard] variant, and frequently come with something very interesting and either abusable like sacrifice or just powerful like Indestructible. 
[autocard]Chromatic Lantern[/autocard] makes me think that people have spoiled by [autocard]Prophetic Prism[/autocard] being so good and they want MOAR. 
Sometime around Mirrodin, Mana Artifacts started getting pushed with the assumption that you'd be playing a 3 or 5 color deck and it might probably have more than 60 cards. 
I think I prefer the Artifacts from Ice Age to Apocalypse as being fun, but not too much, restrained enough that it feels like work to produce good mana, but it's work that's possible to make happen, but obviously superior to ancient backwards ways like the [autocard]Mana Battery[/autocard] >P 7th Edition has some nice [autocard]Diamond[/autocard]s in it that I don't recall where they came from. Possibly Mirage. :)

This is a solid card. It's like a bluer (and therefore weaker) version of Brainwash or Paralyze.  It has a clear advantage over Unsummon in certain faily common situations, like when the creature you're using it on has a low casting cost, or when it has some upkeep penalty to its controller, or when it has haste.
Cheap, and an early form of blue creature control via "tap down."

This isn't that bad, given that it's one-mana removal in a color that generally sucks at removal.  Tapping a creature when it's played is fairly useful all on its own (and remains useful even late-game).But, like a lot of out-of-color effects, you'd probably be better off including a card that does something blue naturally does better, like Unsummon or a counter.

The reason it hasn't been errata'd is because it is functionally different.  If they were to mostly reprint this card, for sure they'd use 'fight', but this doesn't actually fight.  The difference is in what happens if this card leaves play with its activated ability on the stack. OK, there are people that have laughed at this card for years and years because it's a "bird" with "wings" that doesn't have "flying"; here's the deal.  It's an old set from a time when most creatures were often overbalanced for there cost.  That being said, it's a 1/1 creature for 1 mana, put on top of that the fact that it's a green 1/1 creature for 1 mana with a pretty decent (and very rare for green) activated ability that stops creatures like River Boa, Silvos and other annoying regeneraters from doing what they do best. That being said, giving this creature flying as a 1/1 for 1 would make it too powerful to the standards of creature balance that existed at that time.  Yes, they could have made it one more mana and given it flying, but I think this creature is more playable as a single mana 1/1 then a double mana 1/1 with flying.  If this were printed today, due to the increase in average power rating of creatures, they probably would have given this 1 mana 1/1 flying with it's ability, but back in The Dark Days (had to had the pun) of Magic creatures, they decided to not give it flying.

1745.content: A card that was supposed to make land destruction even better than it was, but (fortunately) failed. This could be a pain at some casual tables but never particularly needed to be taken seriously at the tournament level.(@NaturalKiller_Cyborg: there is nothing unclear about this card. With Rampant Growth, the card you searched for is still in your library until you put it into play. If you can't put it into play, it stays in your library, which promptly gets shuffled. Your "solution" would be very bad (even if there were an actual problem for it to solve), because it would still shuffle lands into your library that were trying to come into play, say, from your graveyard. This is obviously not the intended functionality.)
